Homework (due 0126)

Complete the following homework problems for Friday, January 26. Where appropriate, show work that justifies your answers for full credit.

  1. Solve. Express the solutions of the following inequalities in interval notation and shade the region of a number line that corresponds to the solutions:
    1. \(x>2\). The solution in interval notation is \((2,\infty)\) and the graph is
    2. \(x-3\leq 0\). Then \(x\leq 3\). The solution in interval notation is \((-\infty,3]\) and the graph is
    3. \(5-2x< 0\). Then \(5\lt 2x\). Thus \(x\gt \frac{5}{2}.\) The solution in interval notation is \(\left(\frac{5}{2},\infty\right)\) and the graph is
    4. \(3x-5\geq 6x+9\). Then \(-14\geq 3x\). Thus \(x\leq -\frac{14}{3}\). The solution in interval notation is \(\left(-\infty, -\frac{14}{3}\right]\) and the graph is
    5. \(|2x-3|\geq 3\). This is "absolute value greater than number" so this is "or." That is, \(2x-3\geq 3\) or \(2x-3\leq -3\). Thus \(x\geq 3\) or \(x\leq 0\). The solution in interval notation is \((-\infty, 0]\cup[3,\infty)\) and the graph is
    6. \(|3x+6|-5\lt 3\). Then \(|3x+6|\lt 8\). This is "absolute value less than number" so this is "and." Thus \(3x+6\lt 8\) and \(3x+6\gt -8\). Thus \(x\lt\frac{2}{3}\) and \(x\gt -\frac{14}{3}\). The solution in interval notation is \(\left(-\frac{14}{3},\frac{2}{3}\right)\) and the graph is
